data.title: Cannot Debug any .Net Core application
data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 8.1 Enterprise
- .Net Core 1.1 Version: 1.0.0-preview2-003177

2. dotnet restore
3. open folder in VS code
4. click debug

data.title: Retain case in workspaces.json paths

data.title: JS files are not being treated as independent units by default
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

I'm not sure where I read that, but I thought JS files should be treated as independent units by default (by default, I mean no jsconfig.json file). For some reason my VSCode is adding intellisense for non-imported variables across the project. As an example, let's say I have only these two simple files in a folder-project: 

test1.js 
`var foo = 'test';`

test2.js
`var foo = 10;`

So the thing is, I'm getting Intellisense for the wrong foo in test2.js: if I begin to type foo, it's only showing me String.prototype methods. From what I understood, it shouldn't work like that (could be wrong tho, I'm pretty new in VSCode), I want Intellisense only for explicit imported variables, with either commonjs require/es6 import.

I even tried creating a jsconfig.json file, with *allowSyntheticDefaultImports* set to false in jsconfig, but still couldn't make it work the way I want.

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": false
    }
}
```

data.title: Stage lines command does not honor autocrlf

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a repo with a config like:
```
> git config --list
core.symlinks=false
core.autocrlf=true
core.fscache=true
color.diff=auto
color.status=auto
color.branch=auto
color.interactive=true
help.format=html
http.sslcainfo=C:/Program Files/Git/mingw64/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt
diff.astextplain.textconv=astextplain
rebase.autosquash=true
credential.helper=manager
core.editor=code --wait
core.repositoryformatversion=0
core.filemode=false
core.bare=false
core.logallrefupdates=true
core.symlinks=false
core.ignorecase=true
core.autocrlf=true
push.default=simple
```
2. Add a .gitattributes that looks like:
```
* text=auto
```
3. Create a file with crlf line endings
```
foo\r\n
bar\r\n
```
4. Add the file using git add on the command line and commit

5. Change bar to baz in VS Code and save

6. Go to the git tab, select the file, Ctrl-A to select everything, and use the ... menu at the top-right to select stage lines

7. git diff --staged

Expected:
One line changed - bar -> baz, with the line endings lf (due to autocrlf=true)

Actual:
Whole file changed, as the line endings have changed to crlf

data.title: lagging, unresponsive window due to JavaScript intellisense?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. 3000 line JavaScript file with multiple imports (es6), client-side javascript project
2. jsconfig.json to exclude all files except those within my project

Navigating through the file lags a lot (using keyboard arrow keys mostly).  Seems to especially freeze when the cursor lands on a symbol, assumedly trying to infer type, look up symbol reference/declaration.  I get the "Do you want to reload this window" unresponsive error often, but mostly just 1-10 second freezes.

data.title: Diagnostic Hover improvements request
data.body:
I'm working on an extension that tries to put rich security guidance in front of developers as they introduce potential vulnerabilities, and there are a couple of improvements to the hover functionality of a diagnostic that would allow me to improve the overall experience with my extension

1) It would be great to be able to make URLs in the hover into working links, instead of requiring someone to copy the text and paste it in the browser.  I'm reasonably constrained in the length of guidance I can put in a diagnostic, since the hover popup has a max width and height, so I include a URL off to more info on the problem being flagged.  However it would be a lot more usable if the user could just click on this URL and be off to the guidance

2) I would really love to provide different text into the output window versus what I put in the hover window.  Currently, since the diagnostic source and message are echoed to both the output window and hover, but displayed very differently (single line in output vs. a decent sized area in the hover window) I'm in the position of offering a sub optimal experience in one area or the other  (for example, I abbreviate the severity of the security finding to Crit, Imp, Mod, etc. so that it fits well in the output window, but that terseness isn't necessary in the hover window)

I know there is a desire to keep diagnostics lightweight, and I certainly agree with decisions to keep CSS styling out of the mix, but the two requests above would let me deliver a fair bit better user experience to users of my extension.

data.title: Cursor position is wrong after go to definition, then go back, twice
data.body:
- Open textSearch.ts in vscode
- Put the cursor on the `ISerializedFileMatch` in `export class Engine implements ISearchEngine<ISerializedFileMatch>`
- Go to definition
- Go back (cursor is in the right place)
- Go to definition
- Go back (cursor is somewhere else)

This also reproes in stable. In insiders, the cursor is at the top of the file. In stable, it's just off by one line. Trying in other places, it happens in lots of cases but not all. Always every other iteration.

data.title: Menu items should get greyed out if they are are no longer applicable
data.body:
Testing #15811

Menu items should get greyed out if they are are no longer applicable. E.g. Undo/Redo commands should not be displayed if we are at the bottom/top of the undo stack. Same with back/forward. In the cases below, "back" and "redo" both appear to be valid commands, even though they won't do anything.

data.title: Tasks.json Shell Command cannot expand asterisk to match file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Configure tasks.json to run `g++ -g -o main.out *.cpp -std=gnu++14`
```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "g++",
    "isBuildCommand":true,
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["-g", "-o", "main.out", "*.cpp", "-std=gnu++14"],
    "showOutput": "always",
    "echoCommand": true
}
```
2.  Output show the `*.cpp` is passed as-it rather than expanded by the shell
```
running command$ g++ -g -o main.out *.cpp -std=gnu++14
clang: error: no such file or directory: '*.cpp'
clang: error: no input files
```

Also tried to use run `sh g++ -g -o main.out *.cpp`, did not work.
 
The vscode passed the `*.cpp` as `*.cpp`, and if I have a `*.cpp` the task will work.
But the default behavior expected as a Shell Command should be expanding the "*.cpp" to match all files with `.cpp` extension within the same directory.
